body:
No, it's just convenience.

But instead of adding varargs to `withMessageContaining` a new `withMessageContainingAll` could be defined?

What do you think?

Good idea, we'll make the change to `withMessageContainingAll` / `hasMessageContainingAll`.

@antoniomacri are you keen to contribute this improvement ? If so I suggest to wait for #1501 to be resolved to avoid merge conflicts.

issue.title: Support var-arg throwable message assertions (#1501)

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
Update AbstractThrowableAssert and ThrowableAssertAlternative so
that the hasMessageContaining and hasMessageNotContaining now accepts
a var-arg String array.

This unifies the API with the existing String assertions and allows
calls such as this:

	assertThatExceptionOfType(MyException.class).isThrownBy(service::call)
		.withMessageContaining("very")
		.withMessageContaining("bad")
		.withMessageContaining("stuff");

to be simplified to:

	assertThatExceptionOfType(MyException.class).isThrownBy(service::call)
		.withMessageContaining("very", "'bad'", "'stuff'");

#### Check List:
* Fixes #1501
* Unit tests : YES
* Javadoc with a code example (API only) : YES

body:
Actually for consistency with collection assertions `contains`, I suggest we change the existing `with/hasMessageContaining(String)` to  `with/hasMessageContainingFormattedMessage(String, Object...)` .

It will make it obvious what the difference is and with #1501, we are backward compatible so all good.

comments ?

Since we are checking exception messages, the consistency with collections is probably not a big problem.

`hasMessageContainingFormattedMessage` seems ugly to me (maybe better `hasMessageContainingFormattedString`) and is longer than `String.format`, therefore I'd probably keep using the last. ðŸ˜„ ...no ok maybe not, just to avoid the extra parenthesis.

`containsFormattedMessage` (as suggested by Phil [here](https://github.com/joel-costigliola/assertj-core/pull/1503#issuecomment-491558079)) has a subtle difference in its name, since it refers not to the exception itself but actually to its `getMessage` result, that's why `hasMessage...`/`has...` methods are clearer to me.

So I'd probably go with `with/hasMessageContainingAll(String...)` and `with/hasMessageContaining(String, Object...)`.

Good point for `hasMessageContainingFormattedMessage`, having `message` twice is not great.

 `hasMessageContainingFormattedString` is not super elegant, so I'm back to prefer `with/hasMessageContainingAll(String...)` and `with/hasMessageContaining(String, Object...)`.
@antoniomacri are you keen to contribute `with/hasMessageContaining(String, Object...)` ?

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM
